metadata.title: Fe/hollow nano-MgF2: a green and highly-efficient alternative to classical Cr-based catalysts for the gas-phase fluorination reaction†

sections.heading: Catalysis Science & Technology
sections.text:
COMMUNICATION
Cite this: Catal. Sci. Technol., 2019, 9, 3015
Received 11th April 2019, Accepted 21st May 2019
DOI: 10.1039/c9cy00699k
rsc.li/catalysis
Fe/hollow nano-MgF2: a green and highly-efficient alternative to classical Cr-based catalysts for the gas-phase fluorination reaction†
Wei Mao, *ab Zhaohua Jia,a Yanbo Bai,a Yue Qin,a Bo Wang,a Sheng Han,a Wei Zhang,a Liangang Kou,a Jian Lu*a and Erhard Kemnitz *b
A hollow nano-MgF2 supported Fe (Fe/hollow nano-MgF2) nanocatalyst is prepared which is capable of exhibiting excellent
stability under extremely harsh conditions, and has tailored acidity
with weak and medium strengths. In the gas-phase fluorination of
1,1,1,3-tetrachloropropane with HF to 3,3,3-trifluoropropene, Fe/
hollow nano-MgF2 exhibits a similar activity to but a much longer lifespan than classical chromia catalysts under the same reaction
conditions due to its tailored medium-strength acid sites and sta-
ble nanostructure.
Catalytic gas-phase fluorination with anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (aHF) is a crucial process to introduce C–F bonds into organic compounds in industry, which has been applied widely for the production of several million tons of the replacements for chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) per year since the 1990s, such as hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs).1 To date, the element chromium (Cr) is an indispensable component of commercial catalysts in this reaction because it imparts a variety of advanced features to the resulting catalysts, e.g., large surface area with strong surface acidity, and acceptable chemical and structural stability under extremely corrosive conditions.2 However, Cr is a toxic heavy metal which is highly harmful to human health and the environment, leading to serious environmental issues derived from potential Cr pollution which occurs during large-scale applications.3 Furthermore, Crbased catalysts exhibit unsatisfactory performances in the gas-phase fluorination due to serious deactivation resulting from coke formation during the synthesis of hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs), the newest environmentally-benign CFC substitutes.4 Although some attempts have been made to address the above issue by modifying the surface acidity and in-
troducing O2 into the reactor, 4 there is rarely an intrinsic improvement on the catalytic performance of Cr-based catalysts, also causing probably the formation of hazardous CrĲVI), a carcinogenic substance. As a consequence, the development of novel Cr-free catalysts is intensely desirable for establishing a sustainable F-industry.
Previously, only a few catalyst composites, like Fe and Co oxides, and Zn/Al2O3 after pre-treatment with F-gases (HF, haloalkanes, etc.) at elevated temperature, were academically investigated as non-Cr catalysts in the gas-phase fluorination reaction of chlorocarbons.5 However, inadequately fluorinated compounds like CFCs or hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) are mainly formed instead of fully fluorinated HFCs/ HFOs over these catalysts, possibly due to their weak acidity with low surface area. Kemnitz et al. prepared nano FeF3/ MgF2 with a high surface area above 200 m
2 g−1 and strong acidity which was active in the fluorination of C2Cl4.
6a Nonetheless, over-strong acidity led to a low conversion because of acid sites that were blocked by HF,6a a weak molecular acid (pKa = 3.2). Moreover, the microstructural stability of nanometal fluoride catalysts is another big challenge in the extreme circumstances related to high-temperature and corrosive HF which affect the catalyst durability in this reaction.6
Herein, an Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 catalyst is prepared and used for the synthesis of 3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HFO-1243zf), one of the important HFO-candidates,7 via gas-phase fluorination of 1,1,1,3-tetrachloropropane (TCP) with HF. We demonstrate that Fe species are highly dispersed on hollow nanoMgF2 and the nanostructure of the catalyst is stable after pretreatment with HF at elevated temperature and following HFcontact during the reaction, creating numerous surface acid sites with appropriate strength and achieving highly-efficient formation of HFO-1243zf.
Recently, we synthesized nanometal fluorides with high surface area by a new polyol-mediated sol–gel process, such as hollow nano-MgF2.
8 The residual O of hollow nano-MgF2 not only improves significantly the high-temperature stability of the nanomaterial but also reduces its surface acidity.8b In
Catal. Sci. Technol., 2019, 9, 3015–3019 | 3015This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019

E-mail: erhard.kemnitz@chemie.hu-berlin.de † Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available: Experimental details, characterization and catalytic activity data. See DOI: 10.1039/c9cy00699k

3016 | Catal. Sci. Technol., 2019, 9, 3015–3019 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019
this respect, hollow nano-MgF2 may serve as a robust support to achieve highly dispersed Fe, which could combine the merits of both to fabricate a non-Cr catalyst with tailored acidity for gas-phase fluorination. The synthesis details of catalysts are given in the ESI.† To observe the potential structural and textural reconstruction under harsh conditions, Fe/ hollow nano-MgF2 was treated with HF at 350 °C after calcination at the same temperature (denoted as Fe/MgF2 and FFe/MgF2 before and after treatment with HF, respectively). From the images obtained by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), F-Fe/MgF2 (Fig. 1b) seems to preserve almost the same hollow nanosphere-like appearance as Fe/MgF2 (Fig. 1a) with close particle sizes of typical diameter around 7–10 nm, indicating that the treatment process with HF at 350 °C did not cause significant sintering of the nanoparticles. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results (Fig. 1c) which do not show any structural difference are also in line with the TEM images. Only crystalline MgF2 was detected in the XRD patterns of the samples before and after treatment, and the average crystallite size of MgF2, using the Scherrer equation from the {110} facet, increased a bit from 9.7 to 11.2 nm. Although crystalline oxides or fluorides related to the Fe species were not observed in XRD, the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy mapping (EDS-elemental mapping) images of the catalysts (Fig. S1, ESI†) revealed the existence and homogenous distribution of Fe and O on hollow nano-MgF2 before and after treatment with HF at elevated temperature. The trend of indistinguishable change is also reflected in the N2 sorption analysis of the samples (Fig. 1d), displaying a similar type IV isotherm with an H2-type hysteresis loop at high P/P0 (0.7– 1.0) for both Fe/MgF2 and F-Fe/MgF2. These measurements confirm that the Fe species are highly dispersed on hollow nano-MgF2 and the nanostructure of the catalyst remains unchanged under the harsh environment of both hightemperature and HF, in contrast to conventional nanometal fluorides.
From the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Fe/ MgF2 (Fig. 2a), three kinds of lattice fringes were identified and their interplanar distances were scaled to 0.24, 0.27 and 0.25 nm, sequentially corresponding to the facets of α-Fe2O3{400}, FeF3{104} and MgF2{101}.
6b,9a,b Interestingly, iron fluoride nanocrystals were formed in Fe/hollow nanoMgF2 after simple calcination at 350 °C in static air, indicating a strong interaction between the Fe precursor and hollow nano-MgF2 during this process, thus resulting in the partial fluorination of Fe. Notably, the same lattice fringes of α-Fe2O3 and FeF3 were also visible in the HRTEM image of FFe/MgF2 (Fig. 2b), implying that some Fe oxides were stable and not converted into Fe fluorides during the HF treatment. In fact, the cubic metal oxides, like α-Cr2O3 and α-Al2O3, are HF-tolerant even at elevated temperature due to kinetic limitation, although the formation of metal fluorides by reacting the relevant oxides with HF is thermodynamically favored.10 This is a conceivable reason for the stability of α-Fe2O3 during the HF treatment; meanwhile, another explanation, that a strong interaction occurred between the formed α-Fe2O3 and hollow nano-MgF2 support, cannot be excluded. Nevertheless, the content of O decreased from 6.1 wt% to 2.9 wt% as determined by SEM-EDS (Table S1†) after the HF treatment, while the content of F increased from 51.2 wt% to 57.0 wt%, suggesting that the fluorination degree of Fe/hollow nanoMgF2 was enhanced partly. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 2c) provides further evidence for the above findings. The double peaks at Fe 2p3/2 binding energies of ∼711.3 and ∼716.5 eV, assigned to Fe–O of Fe2O3 and Fe–F of FeF3,
9a,c respectively, were distinctly observed both in Fe/MgF2 and F-Fe/MgF2. According to the results of curve fitting, the relative content of FeF3 was 37% in Fe/MgF2 and 45% in F-Fe/MgF2, demonstrating that the Fe oxides were partially transformed into Fe fluorides in the course of HF treatment.
NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements (Fig. 2d and Table 1) reveal that the

Catal. Sci. Technol., 2019, 9, 3015–3019 | 3017This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2019
enhancement of fluorination degree of Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 influences its surface acidity. The NH3-TPD profile of Fe/ MgF2 was composed of a main broad peak in the region of 110–380 °C centered at 180 °C and a minor peak centered at 437 °C, implying that acid sites with various strengths (weak to strong) were present. After HF treatment, the maximum center of the main peak shifted to 259 °C with the presence of a new shoulder peak at 357 °C for F-Fe/MgF2, and the minor peak also moved to a high temperature of 482 °C. Besides, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy analyses for pyridine adsorbed (Fig. S2†) show that Lewis acid sites were predominant in Fe/MgF2 and F-Fe/MgF2. Obviously, the HF treatment led to an increase of acidic strength for Fe/hollow nano-MgF2, which is plausibly ascribed to the raised content of Fe fluorides on the surface. In contrast, the amounts of acid sites on Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 (Table 1), especially the strong acid sites, decreased after the HF treatment, owing to the surface area decline derived from somewhat aggregation of nanoparticles. It should be noted that there was no dramatic reduction of the specific surface area of Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 after the HF treatment at 350 °C which still reached a high value of 87 m2 g−1. For comparison, we prepared a classical Cr-based catalyst (F-Cr2O3) and fluorinated Fe/MgO (F-Fe/MgO) by using nano-MgO (SBET = 220 m2 g−1) instead of hollow nano-MgF2 under the same HF treatment as Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 (details in the ESI†). F-Cr2O3 (Fig. 2d) exhibited a similar NH3-TPD profile to F-Fe/ MgF2, but with two different maxima at 201 and 540 °C. This means that stronger acidic sites are present on F-Cr2O3 than on F-Fe/MgF2. Although a bit lower specific surface area for F-Fe/MgF2 led to a smaller total acid amount than that of F-Cr2O3, the amounts, in particular the distributions of the weak and medium acid sites, were close for both catalysts. However, using nano-MgO as the support, the sample after the HF treatment displayed a much lower specific surface area with very limited acid sites.
Such a nanostructure, numerous acid sites with tailored weak and medium strengths, and good stability against an extremely corrosive environment make F-Fe/MgF2 a promising solid-acid catalyst, especially for high-temperature reactions under harsh conditions like gas-phase fluorinations. To illustrate the catalytic benefits of Fe/hollow nano-MgF2, the catalytic behaviors in the gas-phase fluorination of TCP with HF over F-Fe/MgF2 and F-Cr2O3 were examined in a fix-bed
reactor at 260 °C and 1 bar (Fig. 3), resulting in the formation of HFO-1243zf, the targeted product that well represents typical HFOs employed as the newest environmentally-safe replacements of CFCs in refrigeration.7 F-Fe/MgF2 showed a high initial TCP conversion (∼100%) which was maintained constantly over the first 100 h, then the catalyst activity began to decay gradually with the TCP conversion decreasing to 85% within 205 h. For comparison, F-Cr2O3 displayed a remarkably rapid deactivation rate with the TCP conversion decreasing from 99% to 77% after 72 h of reaction time. In addition, the gas-phase fluorination reaction of TCP was also carried out over the F-Fe/MgO catalyst (the results are not shown here), where the TCP conversion declined sharply from 100% to 50% within 50 h due to the quite limited catalyst acidity. Simultaneously, the HFO-1243zf selectivity of F-Cr2O3 also displayed a much faster deactivation rate than that of F-Fe/MgF2, although a bit higher initial selectivity was observed over F-Cr2O3. Noticeably, after a rapid decline within the first 30 h, the HFO-1243zf selectivity of F-Fe/MgF2 was maintained basically at 91–92% over the rest of the 205 h course. Besides HFO-1243zf, CF3–CH2–CH2Cl was the secondary product (GC concentration of 4–6%) over the F-Fe/ MgF2 and F-Cr2O3 catalysts, and there were at least three other unknown trace products that cannot be identified currently. Presumably, TCP can be transformed easily to CF3– CH2–CH2Cl under our catalytic system by the consecutive Cl/ F exchange reactions, but subsequently the dehydrochlorination of CF3–CH2–CH2Cl to HFO-1243zf is slow. Catalyst durability is a very significant aspect for the commercialization of heterogeneous catalysts. Therefore, the significantly better

catalytic activity and stability of F-Fe/MgF2 in comparison to the state of the art F-Cr2O3 under comparable reaction conditions is a promising finding for future catalyst developments.
The remarkable catalytic performance of F-Fe/MgF2 towards the gas-phase fluorination of TCP can be traced back to its appropriate acidity with good stability at high temperature and in an HF environment. As the NH3-TPD results revealed, the similar initial catalytic activities for F-Fe/MgF2 and F-Cr2O3 are attributed to their similarities in the amount and distributions of weak and medium acid sites. However, the less strong acid sites in nanostructured F-Fe/MgF2 do not obviously result in or at least cause much less coke formation,11 thus making F-Fe/MgF2 a superior catalyst over F-Cr2O3. The XRD pattern (Fig. S3†), N2-sorption isotherm (Fig. S4†) and XPS spectrum (Fig. S5†) of used F-Fe/MgF2 demonstrate that F-Fe/MgF2 preserved its topology, texture, and surface Fe species, and remained almost stable upon long-term reaction. However, Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S6†) shows that the bands assigned to carbon species appeared in the used F-Fe/MgF2 and F-Cr2O3, implying carbonaceous deposition accounting for catalyst deactivation. The SEM-EDS results disclose that the content of C increased notably to 10.3 wt% and 12.4 wt%, respectively, on the used F-Fe/MgF2 and F-Cr2O3, in line with the Raman analysis. Thus, although carbon deposition is observed even in the case of the used FFe/MgF2, this is obviously formed on the surface sites which are not crucial for the fluorination process, different to F-Cr2O3. The TEM image (Fig. 4) of F-Fe/MgF2 used after 205 h on-stream shows that the deposition of carbonaceous materials affected the morphology of the catalyst to a certain extent, leading to partial agglomeration. However, the primary nanoparticles with a hollow spherical structure did not collapse or sinter severely, which remained intact.
In conclusion, we have demonstrated for the first time highly-efficient gas-phase fluorination with HF on a non-Cr catalyst, Fe/hollow nano-MgF2, for the production of HFOs. The nanostructure of hollow nano-MgF2 supported Fe catalysts displayed extraordinary stability under extremely corrosive conditions, including pre-treatment with HF at 350 °C and the subsequent long-term fluorination reaction, compared to previ-
ously reported nanometal fluoride materials. Furthermore, acid sites of weak and medium strengths are present on the surface of Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 after the HF treatment, and the amount and distribution of which are similar to those of classically used F-Cr2O3 catalysts. By taking the aforementioned advantages, Fe/hollow nano-MgF2 exhibited superior catalytic performance as compared with F-Cr2O3 in the gasphase fluorination of TCP to HFO-1243zf in terms of activity and durability, reaching attractive levels for commercialization. Accordingly, our findings provide a successful strategy for developing green alternatives to classical Cr-based catalysts for the sustainable production of CFC substitutes by gas-phase fluorination reactions. The unique features of Fe/hollow nanoMgF2 are also promising for a wide range of other relevant acid-catalyzed reactions that could benefit from its stability under harsh conditions and mild acidity.

metadata.abstractText: A hollow nano-MgF2 supported Fe (Fe/hollow nano-MgF2) nanocatalyst is prepared which is capable of exhibiting excellent stability under extremely harsh conditions, and has tailored acidity with weak and medium strengths. In the gas-phase fluorination of 1,1,1,3-tetrachloropropane with HF to 3,3,3-trifluoropropene, Fe/ hollow nano-MgF2 exhibits a similar activity to but a much longer lifespan than classical chromia catalysts under the same reaction conditions due to its tailored medium-strength acid sites and stable nanostructure.
